Notes: Starting 8 November all schools in NSW will operate on updated Level 3 settings for the rest of Term. Level 3 is a relaxation of COVID restrictions made of of a combination of layered safety measures allowing student and staff wellness while keeping schools open. This provision has allowed for more school activities including dancing and some music classes, school sports, and now fully vaccinated visitors being allowed on site to support curriculum delivery, wellbeing programs and school operations.    Continuing 25 October policy is still in place where schools of all grades have returned to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. While in indoor settings in schools, masks or face coverings are required for all staff and all students in Year 7 and above. Masks are strongly recommended for primary students.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119173807/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families

No new policy. Continuing from 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. However, music festivals still can't be held in NSW.   Other restrictions vary by region but generally are eased for people who are fully vaccinated or have a medical exemption. Generally indoor events have a capacity restriction of 75 per cent but outdoor events have 100 per cent capacity with social distancing. Example: A maximum of 2,000 people can attend a controlled, ticketed outdoor event if theyâre assigned a specific seat â subject to 1 person per 2 square metres. A maximum of 500 people can attend a controlled, ticketed outdoor event if theyâre allocated to a designated seating area â subject to 1 person per 2 square metres. Indoor entertainment facilities can sell tickets for seated events at 75 per cent of fixed seating capacity or no more than 1 person per 2 square metres on the premises. Outdoor entertainment facilities can sell tickets for seated events at 100 per cent of fixed seating capacity or no more than 1 person per 2 square metres on the premises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210620091338/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/nsw  https://web.archive.org/web/20210708181532/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/vic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022184508/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/22/melbourne-covid-lockdown-ends-lifts-today-friday-victoria-end-lift-change-what-are-the-new-restrictions-rules-freedoms-reopening-plan  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022043759/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions/80-percent

No new policy. Continuing policy for fully vaccinated travelers from New Zealand who test negative in pre-departure COVID tests can enter Australia. They would be allowed to skip quarantine in certain jurisdictions like New South Wales, but those conditions may differ in other states and territories. Other countries restricts travel to Australia where travel is only available if you are exempt or you have been granted an individual exemption (even if you have been vaccinated). All travelers entering Australia from overseas will be quarantined in a hotel or designated facility for 14 days. Travelers are required to undertake their mandatory 14-day quarantine at their port of entry.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094008/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094556/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-and-restrictions/international-travel-and-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094513/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/01/australia-reopens-its-borders-to-new-zealand-and-singapore.html

No new policy. Continuing from 29 Oct Regional Victoria and Metropolitan Melbourne are now under the same rules, and masks are no longer mandatory outdoors. You must wear a face mask in all indoor settings. Restrictions for the other regions vary by region but generally masks are required in certain public spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211102092302/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/face-masks/vic    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004184048/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-case-numbers-and-statistics

Effective Monday 15  - Monday 22 November 2021 Northern Territories (NT) Greater Katherine and Robinson River including surrounding homelands entered into a full lockdown.  Everyone must wear a mask outside of their home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175131/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175313/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt

Effective 21 November 2021 more lockdowns are being put in place across the Northern Territories. The Lajamanu community and the surrounding homelands are in a lockdown until 6pm on 11 December 2021. The municipality of Katherine including Rockhole are in a lockout until 12pm Tuesday 7 December 2021. Robinson River, including surrounding homelands are in a lockout until Wednesday 1 December 2021. Binjari is in a hard lockdown.    Everyone must wear a mask outside of their home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129211745/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129211815/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout

Some areas previously in lockdown are transitioning to a "lockout" (Lajamanu community effective 1 Dec and Municipality of Katherine effective 27 Nov).  During a lockout, fully vaccinated residents can live normally within a lockout area.     Continuing from 21 November, Binjari is still in lockdown but will transition from a lockdown to a lockout midday Tuesday 7 December 2021. Everyone must wear a mask outside of their home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206201410/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206201535/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/lockdown-lockout

No new policies. Continuing from 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20211021011733/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

No significant changes since the general tightening of measures on the 9th of August, except for the suspension of most in-patient dental procedures and services.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "ii) All officers and staff, whether government or private are required to do work-from-home. Only really needed staff are allowed to go out to work such as,    frontline workers (health sector, security sector, hospitality sector, transport sector)  daily necessities sector (food, retail business)  facilities and utilities sector (electricity, water, telecommunications)  officers at the borders and entrances to Brunei Darussalam  oil and gas and downstream sectors  development sector  agri-food and forestry sectors"    See the Ministry of Health's initial press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Ministry of Health's press release on dental procedures (dated 15th August), archived at https://archive.vn/BAxD8

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

No changes.    After local transmission cases were found in Brunei on 07 Aug in over a year, public transport capacity was reduced effective from 09 Aug.    Per the press release of 08 Aug by the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, written in Malay,    "1.3.1 Public transport operators are limited to 50 per cent seating capacity in public transport vehicles."    People are also encouraged to stay at home through the "Operasi Pulih" programme.    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/dkRj1  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Pulih published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August. People are required to stay at home, except for essential purposes (for example, going to work for essential workers, buying groceries, or attending funerals and weddings).    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    This is further reiterated under Operasi Pulih, where "The enhanced restrictions to limit movement between 8pm to 4am announced yesterday under Operasi Pulih (Recovery Operation) is aimed at stopping the public from going out to visit and gather with others, with the exception of essential workers who need to go out to work for the good of society.    This was shared by Minister at the Prime Ministerâs Office and Minister of Finance and Economy II Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mohd Amin Liew bin Abdullah during a press conference yesterday, in addition to the strengthening of enforcement agenciesâ activities and public cooperation in aiding the government through the newly introduced 24-hour hotline, as well as involvement of penghulus and village heads in monitoring residents, which are important to ensure people reduce movement."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Pulih published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 05 Nov, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/LLpFZ  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 09 Nov (https://archive.vn/sNuJG) and 10 Nov (https://archive.vn/6h9mp).    No updates were missing.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 10 Nov,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/LLpFZ  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 10 Nov,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/LLpFZ

Vaccination groups: Phase 1, 2 and 3 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases  and  Phase 3: individuals aged 18 years and above    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For Covid-19 For The Phase Three" (dated 01 Jul), archived at https://archive.vn/M1nb1  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm  The Ministry of Health's press release "COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled "Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i  The Star Online's report, entitled "Brunei: Over 76, 000 received Covid-19 vaccination as country goes 417 without local cases" (dated 28 Jun), archived at https://archive.is/7F2bK  Xinhua's report, entitled "Brunei continues COVID-19 vaccination with China's Sinopharm donations" (dated 16 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/k5deH  The Scoop's report, entitled "MoH: Two jabs 83% effective in preventing COVID-19 infection" (dated 15 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/5NITD  The Scoop's report, entitled "AstraZeneca is now Bruneiâs default vaccine" (dated 18 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/SbAOq  The Ministry of Health's press release "Contribution of Moderna Vaccine from Singapore" (dated 28 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/kgAa3

No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

Wang Dengfeng, director of the Prevention and Control Office of the Ministry of Education and director of the Department of Physical Education, Health and Arts Education, said on Nov. 13, 2021, that all teachers and students should have their body temperature tested when they enter the school, and all of them should pay attention to their health status and travel trajectory, and strictly implement all measures for the prevention and control of the epidemic in the school. https://web.archive.org/web/20211201024231/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/fkdt/202111/4ed1e55f05af44e0a4b2d2fc52b99afe.shtml

Wang Dengfeng, director of the Prevention and Control Office of the Ministry of Education and director of the Department of Physical Education, Health and Arts Education, said on Nov. 13, 2021, that all teachers and students should have their body temperature tested when they enter the school, and all of them should pay attention to their health status and travel trajectory, and strictly implement all measures for the prevention and control of the epidemic in the school.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211201024231/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/fkdt/202111/4ed1e55f05af44e0a4b2d2fc52b99afe.shtml

Shanxi Provincial Health and Wellness Commission declared on 2021-11-28: All tourist places such as attractions and scenic spots, accommodation places such as hotels, guesthouses and B&Bs, and gathering places such as superstores, theaters, bars and Internet cafes should strictly implement preventive and control measures such as wearing masks, testing body temperature, checking health codes and trip cards for all entering personnel, and strictly check the proof of negative nucleic acid tests within 48 hours for those who have a history of travel and residence in medium to high risk areas and cities where the epidemic occurs within 14 days, and those who cannot provide it should not enter and immediately report to the local epidemic prevention and control departments.  https://web.archive.org/http://www.shanxi.gov.cn/ztjj/yqfkzccs/sjzccs/202111/t20211129_946140.shtml

2021.11.26,Shanghai Municipal Culture and Tourism Bureau on the city's suspension of cross-province group travel and "air ticket + hotel" business notice: travel agencies and online travel enterprises should strictly follow the "Travel Agency New Coronary Pneumonia Epidemic Prevention and Control Guidelines (Third Edition)" requirements, from strict to tight, detailed and practical to do a good job in the recruitment of tourists, organization, reception and other aspects of the epidemic prevention and control work, and strictly control the size of the tour group.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206160618/https://www.shanghai.gov.cn/sjzccs/20211126/f211cb72b4f54059b011d4affabb7ceb.html

Shanxi Provincial Health Commission on 2021-12-03 statement: highways, railroads, civil aviation and other transportation stations to strengthen passenger flow guidance, to avoid the gathering of people.  https://web.archive.org/http://www.shanxi.gov.cn/ztjj/yqfkzccs/sjzccs/202112/t20211203_946786.shtml

Tianjin Municipal People's Government Air Defense Command Office November 28, 2021 release information: key land port city control: after the study, the implementation of China's key land port city to return to Tianjin 14 days after arrival medical observation, and 1, 3, 7, 14 days to implement nucleic acid testing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206144011/https://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/202111/t20211128_5735049.html

The Office of the Air Defense Command of the Tianjin Municipal People's Government issued information on December 6, 2021: Relevant people should take the initiative to report, and those who come to and return to Tianjin with a negative nucleic acid certificate within 48 hours or a health code "green code" containing negative nucleic acid test information, should take the initiative to report to the community, work units, etc., and cooperate with the implementation of various preventive and control measures such as home isolation (co-isolation of people living together, centralized isolation if they do not meet the conditions of home isolation), new coronavirus nucleic acid test, health monitoring, etc. for 14 days after leaving the exposed place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143402/https://www.tj.gov.cn/sy/ztzl/tjsfyyqfkzt/sjzcwj/

Qinhuangdao City Government on November 24, 2021 issued into the local policy: entry personnel, the first place of entry 14 days of intensive isolation medical observation, the end of isolation to return to Qin after the implementation of 7 days of intensive isolation medical observation, after the release of isolation to continue to implement 7 days of home medical observation. If the first place of entry to complete 21 days of centralized isolation, after arriving in Qin continue to implement 7 days of home medical observation. Where there is no 1 person 1 home conditions, to Qin after returning to Qin closed-loop transfer to a designated isolation site for 7 days of centralized isolation medical observation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206152547/http://www.hebei.gov.cn/hebei/15067610/15068061/15069945/index.html

Effective at 8am 20th November 2021, 'social gatherings' or 'congregations' shall be limited to no more than 25 persons indoors or 75 persons outdoors, regardless of vaccination status. This shall include patrons, guests, participants, employees and vendors. There shall be no more than 10 persons per group or table indoors.  Organisers of events, such as sporting events, concerts, outreach activities, night markets, fiestas, truck rallies and other similar events, are responsible for implementing and enforcing the minimum requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211126091516/https://governor.guam.gov/wp-content/ordersfiles/21.1119%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-29%20-%20Relative%20to%20Amending%20Vaccination%20Requirements%20for%20Certain%20Establishments%20and%20Activities,%20Limitations%20on%20Social%20Gatherings,%20and%20Restrictions%20for%20Incoming%20Travelers%20and%20Quarantine%20Facilities.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20211129081855/https://ghs.guam.gov/sites/default/files/dphss-guidance-memo-2022-05-reamendments-on-vaccination-requirements-11.19.2021-1.pdf

Take Precautions Now: Prevent the Spread of All Respiratory Illnesses  The potential public health threat posed by COVID-19 is high, globally, nationally, and to our island. Individual risk is dependent on exposure. Everyone in our community can take steps now to prepare for this emerging public health threat by doing everyday preventative measures:  Itâs currently flu and respiratory disease season and CDC recommends getting a flu vaccine, taking everyday preventive actions to help stop the spread of germs, and taking flu antivirals if prescribed.  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. However, if soap and water are not readily available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.  Avoid touching your mouth, eyes, and nose with unwashed hands.  Avoid close contact with people who are sick.  Practice proper cough etiquette â cover your mouth and nose with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects or surfaces.  Stay home when you are sick â do not go to work or school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203202734/https://www.grta.guam.gov/precautionary-measures-department-public-health

As part of Guamâs ongoing effort to contain the spread of COVID-19, individuals entering Guam by air or sea shall be subject to a 10-day quarantine, except as provided herein. Passengers seeking exemption from quarantine under this section must present the following at the port of entry upon arrival:  1. Photo identification (e.g., passport, driverâs license, state-issued identification); and  2. Valid negative COVID-19 molecular test result collected no more than 3 days prior to departure (boarding a flight to Guam); or  3. Valid negative COVID-19 antigen test result collected no more than 1 day prior to departure (boarding a flight to Guam).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211205182930/https://guamrecovery.com/travel-to-guam-guam-recovery-safety-guidelines/

The PUA program, in general, provides up to 39 weeks of unemployment benefits. Guamâs PUA Weekly Benefit Amount (WBA) is $345 a week. Employees who have been laid off or furloughed due to COVID-19 qualify for the full amount. Employees still working but making less than $345 a week qualify for PUA minus their wages. Those making $345 or more do not qualify for PUA    https://web.archive.org/web/20211205185916/https://guamrecovery.com/employee-information-programs-assistance/

Authorities continue to impose domestic long-distance travel restrictions. Individuals traveling by air must provide a vaccination card indicating at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine and a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours of departure; fully vaccinated travelers may provide negative rapid antigen test result taken within 24 hours instead. People traveling by land or sea must provide a vaccination card indicating at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine and a negative rapid antigen test result taken within the last seven days; unvaccinated travelers must show a negative rapid antigen test result taken within 24 hours. All air and sea domestic travelers must also register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel; officials advise travelers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application. No change to previous policy.  As all precautionary measures have now been lifted in all prefectures, schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.  Schools have also resumed all club activities, events, and excursions; however strict infection control measures must be followed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041455/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

No change to previous policy.  Time restrictions on restaurants and alcohol service have been lifted in all prefectures.  Infection control continue to be recommended for all businesses, however no closures are in place for any industry. No change to previous policy.  All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    For events that require attendees to move across the country, the government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. However, if necessary, when holding an event that involves nationwide movement or an event with more than 1,000 participants, event holders may also consult directly with city or prefectural authorities to safely hold the event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041455/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041621/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020465.html (Tokyo Oct 31-Nov 30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112041636/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020468.html (Tokyo FAQ)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034542/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028taishohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106034546/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1028eigo.pdf (Okinawa Nov 1-30)

No change to previous policy.  All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity. A precautionary measure that is no longer required starting December 1:  For events in Tokyo requiring attendees to move across the country, when holding an event that involves nationwide movement or an event with more than 1,000 participants, event safety logistics no longer needs to be reviewed by the Tokyo local government.    All public events have resumed. The government has provided detailed guidelines on infection control measures to reduce risk of outbreaks, including providing separate entrances and exits, and limiting personnel depending on venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203023515/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012156/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020631.html (Tokyo basic measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012221/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html (Tokyo basic gathering measures from Dec 1)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130012732/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1125hoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa basic measures from Nov 25)

No change to previous policy. All public events have resumed.  For events with no loud cheering/shouting, a maximum of 5000 people are permitted to attend up to a venue's full capacity.  For events with loud cheering/shouting, gatherings may occur up to half a venue's capacity.    For events that require attendees to move across the country, the government is encouraging those events to be cancelled. On November 8, Japan has shortenedthe quarantine period to 3-days for all incoming fully vaccinated travellers. International students on scolarships with Japanese universities are also permitted to enter Japan. However, The government continues to limit the number of people allowed to enter the country per day to 3,500, including Japanese citizens.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044348/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013338331000.html (international students and business quarantine)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044708/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041148/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100256050.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044919/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C138.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112044943/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

Although Japan had begun permitting international students and business travellers in, on November 28 and 29, they had announce restrictions would come back in place due to concerns over the Omicron variant. Effective November 30, Japan would suspend all entry of planned flights for international students and business travellers for all countries.  Up until this point, Japan still has not permitted entry to those that do not hold a valid VISA and all short-term entry for tourism means continue to be barred. Including naturalized citizens of Japan, the number of individuals Japan had permitted entry had only been 3,500 people a day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004647/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211129/k10013366101000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004816/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C145.html%5C

On November 30, Japan's ban on all entry of planned flights for international students and business travellers comes into effect.  While Japan had announced they would be increasing arriving passengers to 5,000 per day on November 18th, the country will now reduce daily incoming travellers, including naturalized citizens of Japan, back down to 3,500 per day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203023002/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211130/k10013367681000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004647/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211129/k10013366101000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130004816/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C145.html%5C  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203022540/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/11/18/national/japan-increase-entry-cap-5000/

On December 1st, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism in Japan will be suspending new bookings on all international flights coming into Japan for the entire month of December. This means that even Japanese nationals, will not be able to return into the country before 2022 if they have not yet booked a flight during December.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032256/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369861000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032549/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370951000.html

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20, p.24).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112045328/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 20).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112045328/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002319/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112045420/https://corona.go.jp/action

In preparation of wave 6 of infections, the government is considering offering free PCR and rapid antigen testing to all individuals including those who are asymptomatic. However, as of now, only symptomatic and those in close contact with a positive case are eligible for free testing.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.  Rapid antigen tests are also freely available to prevent potential outbreaks in schools. Rapid antigen tests are also being sold to the general public in pharmacies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041522/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050713/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050801/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/

On November 12, the Japanese government announces change in testing policy. As a pre-emptive measure in preparations for countering against a sixth wave of infection, free PCR and antigen testing have become available for asymptomatic individuals.    Despite the announcement we cannot find any firm dates when the policy comes in to force. Should dates become clearer at a leter date we will adjust the policy accordingly.    Kishida announced Friday that, while new cases are rising, individuals who canât be vaccinated for health reasons and who donât have symptoms but are concerned they have been infected can receive a PCR or antigen test before taking part in certain economic or social activities.    The plan is part of a greater effort to prepare the country for a sixth wave of the pandemic â and whatever comes afterwards â by bolstering hospitals, procuring more medical staff, expanding its vaccine campaign, administering booster shots and advancing the treatment of those with COVID-19.    âWhile new cases have declined substantially, itâs important to acknowledge the strong possibility that the virus will return and to prepare accordingly,â Kishida said Friday.    Itâs not exactly clear who will be eligible and under what circumstances, but Kishida said Friday that the decision will be left to local governments, who have been directed to execute the plan at the latest by the end of March 2022.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211114022125/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/11/12/national/covid19-policies-free-testing/    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050612/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/politics/20211107-OYT1T50148/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050745/https://toyokeizai.net/articles/-/469112  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119042821/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013349111000.html (logistics for free asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112050813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211108/k10013339271000.html (considerations for asymptomatic testing)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119050557/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119045214/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

While the federal government in Japan is calling on individual locals to prepare for the administration of free PCR test, prefectures have by the end of March 2022 to fully implement the policy.  In Tokyo, the government has announced free PCR testing will become available for those who cannot be vaccinated by mid-December in preparations for the sixth wave of infections.  In Mie, free PCR testing for asymptomatic individuals who live, work, or attend school in the prefecture are eligible from October 11, 2021 to December 10, 2021.  In Tokushima, free PCR testing for asymptomatic individuals is in place but only for those returning into Tokushima prefecture by December 31, 2021.  In Kagawa, the government has announced they will provide free PCR testing for asymptomatic returning individuals into Kagawa from December 6.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130020746/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211125/k10013360981000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022324/https://www.pref.mie.lg.jp/KANSENJO/HP/m0348600003_00006.htm (Mie)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130021340/https://www.pref.tokushima.lg.jp/ippannokata/kenko/kansensho/5048105/ (Tokushima)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130021740/https://jizenpcr-tokushima.jp/ (Tokushima)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022011/https://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/14478063 (Kagawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130021958/https://www.fnn.jp/articles/-/274262 (Kagawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022533/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211130022547/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

Nagano and Shimane prefectures have announced they will be offering free PCR testing for those returning home for the end of the year from outside the prefecture. Testing will be available until December 31, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203034053/https://www.nbs-tv.co.jp/news/articles/2021120200000002.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203034116/https://www.sanin-chuo.co.jp/articles/-/130101

60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. There is no evidence that contact tracing in Tokyo has improved.    Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama contact tracing overwhelmed)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041736/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. On November 11, the government authorizes the Pfizer vaccine to be used for third dose vaccination set to begin in December.  Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054416/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211111/k10013343621000.html (Pfizer third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

The government announces vaccination for 5-11 year olds are currently under the review process and is expected to begin February 2022 at the earliest.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose. There are also no-reservation vaccination clinics available for non-Japanese speakers with clinic attendees who are able to communicate in multiple foreign languages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044541/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211117/k10013351001000.html (5-11 year olds)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119044634/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211115/k10013348971000.html (non-Japanese speakers)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106042219/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054622/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054719/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

In preparations for to begin third dose vaccinations on December 1, 2021, governments of each regional local have been sending out vaccination invitations to medical professionals across the country. Previously the government had announced that only those who had received their second dose 8-months prior qualify for third doses at this time. However, they have since revised this timeline to 6-months for targeted personnel that either work or reside in places identified as high transmission risk such as long term care homes or medical institutions.    As of November 22, 2021, 76.2% of all of Japan's population has received 2-doses.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose. There are also no-reservation vaccination clinics available for non-Japanese speakers with clinic attendees who are able to communicate in multiple foreign languages.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129185518/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211122/k10013357501000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129185921/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211124/k10013359281000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190056/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211122/k10013357771000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190256/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190233/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.htm (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129190302/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

On December 1, third doses begin being administered to healthcare workers. The government is targeting a total of 1.04 million medical staff in December.  In January, 2 million medical workers, 610,000 elderly people aged 65 and over, and 420,000 people aged 64 and under who received the second vaccination early will become eligible.  In Feburary, 1.83 million medical workers and 11.6 million elderly people, 730,000 under 64 years old will be eligible.  In March, 890,000 medical workers, 16.24 million elderly people, 64 years old or younger In addition to 4.35 million people, 1.68 million people who are "work-related inoculations" conducted at companies and universities are also eligible.  In April, 3.13 million elderly people, 11.94 million people under 64 years old, 5 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  In May, 580,000 elderly people, 14.62 million people under 64 years old, 1.55 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  In June, 350,000 elderly people, 12.73 million under 64 years old, and 2.48 million occupational inoculations will be eligible and continue until September 2022.    Mass vaccination sites operated by the Self-Defence Forces in Tokyo and Osaka have now closed. All vaccination sites continue and be operated by prefectural and municipal governments.    Children age 5-11 in Japan will likely begin vaccinations in February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203032146/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369651000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211203033017/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211130/k10013368491000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211202173408/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211202/k10013370651000.html

Some visitation at elderly care homes continue to be restricted. The government is considering the resumption of visitations for fully vaccinated visitors.    Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of November 4, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly also continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Supply infection prevention items such as masks, other PPE, and disinfectants,  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054033/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211110/k10013341201000.html (visitations for fully vaccinated visitors)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054232/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054206/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211112054300/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/

In response to global COVID-19 developments, the Cambodian Ministry of?Health announced the following guidelines effective as of November 29, 2021:    Effective 29 November, in order to curb the spread of the COVID-19 Omicron variant, all travelers who have been physically present or have transited Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Angola and Zambia will be prohibited entry into the Kingdom of Cambodia.  The public is directed to wear masks, use?hand sanitizers and?practice?social distancing. The Curfew Order introduced in July 2021, which refers to restrictions on gatherings, continues to be listed under official Government pages with no further update ( http://archive.today/2021.09.30-061704/https://www.president.gov.ki/resources/gazettes-instruments.html ), however there are no recent references to this curfew order or restrictions on gatherings in official facebook pages.  Photographs of gatherings from Facebook pages do not suggest that this order is current and the Police department page (https://www.facebook.com/kiribatipolice) makes no reference to infringement or enforcement of this order.

The Curfew Order introduced in July 2021 continues to be listed under official Government pages (http://archive.today/2021.09.30-061704/https://www.president.gov.ki/resources/gazettes-instruments.html), however there are no recent references to the curfew on official facebook pages and the US Embassy in Fiji (see drop down for Kiribati on http://archive.today/2021.11.08-183618/https://fj.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/) reports there is no curfew in place ("Is a curfew in place? No").  Although references were made to the curfew order on the police facebook page on 28th July and 2nd August 2021, no further references have been identified since then.  It is therefore unclear whether the curfew remains in place.

As noted previously, border closure was extended to end of 2021.   In September an announcement was made by the president setting out intentions to re-open borders from January 2022.  No further announcements on border opening have been found.    RNZ News, 10th September 2021    "Kiribati intends opening its borders in January next year.    The announcement was made in a national address this week by the Kiribati President, Taneti Maamau, on Radio Kiribati."    http://archive.today/2021.09.13-163857/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/451187/in-brief-news-from-around-the-pacific    US Embassy page (http://archive.today/2021.11.08-183618/https://fj.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/) notes that "Entry to Kiribati is highly restricted."
https://archive.md/AGL5H  For the first time since South Korea began battling its coronavirus outbreak in early 2020, all schools across the country resumed full-time in-person classes on Monday.

https://archive.md/QelU7  Starting Monday till Jan. 2, the maximum number of people at private gatherings will be cut to six in the greater Seoul area and eight in other areas, from the current 10 and 12.

https://archive.md/3oyAW  The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency called an emergency meeting Saturday evening with 13 ministries and announced that all foreigners who have been in the newly listed African countries will be refused entry to Korea.

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Laos? Yes    If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes    For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to U.S. Centers for Disease Controlâs (CDC) requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID-19 test  U.S. citizens can obtain a COVID-19 test in Laos at The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE)  in Vientiane. The following information of U.S. citizens is needed to obtain a COVID-19 test: 1. Copy of Passport, 2. Itinerary, 3. A fee of 650,000 Lao kip (approximately $65) may be necessary for U.S. citizens. There are some exceptions to the cost of testing for diplomatic travelers.    A physical copy of test result will be available to pick up within 3 to 5 hours after collection of the sample (for urgent cases, results can be obtained within one hour)    The National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology (NCLE) is the central authority for COVID-19 in Laos (tel: 021-312351.)  In order to be tested for COVID-19, you must qualify under the following testing criteria:    All new entrees to Laos;  People who have symptoms of COVID-19;  People with severe acute respiratory infection;  People who will travel abroad (and are approved by the Government of Laos COVID-19 Task Force)  There may be fees for each COVID-19 test of up 1.2 million Lao kip (approximately $130), depending on your visa class.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210913134902/https://la.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Movement Restrictions:    Is a curfew in place? No  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Social distancing requirements:  The Macau government requires the use of the Macau Health Code for entrance to certain locations like immigration buildings, medical institutions, casinos, hotels, and guesthouses. Similarly, temperature checks are mandatory in many settings. For more details, please see the Macau governmentâs COVID-19 website.  As part of the Government of Macauâs declaration of a state of immediate pandemic prevention on September 25, 2021, many regular services in Macau were suspended. The declaration on October 4, 2021 means most of these suspensions will continue. Education institutions, set to resume classes on October 3, 2021, will now be suspended until further notice.  Schools may launch home learning according to their own discretion. The Social Welfare Bureau will continue to suspend the operation of subsidized nursery facilities, non-residential and non-emergency social facilities. Residential homes and emergency support services will remain open during this period. See this government press release for more information. On September 25, 2021, ferry services between Macau and Shenzhen and Macau and Zhuhaiâs Wanzai Port were suspended until further notice. Beginning October 6, 2021, certain recreational facilities like cinemas, theatres, indoor amusement parks, game centers, cybercafes, billiard rooms, bowling centers, saunas, massage parlors, beauty salons, gyms, health clubs, karaoke lounges, bars, nightclubs, discotheques, dance parlors, and cabaret venues will be closed. To learn more about closures or cancellations of other Macau services, please check back on the Macau governmentâs website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211116185742/https://hk.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry to Macao  The Macao government has announced that all travellers arriving in Macao, who are not residents of Macao, Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China, will be denied entry. There are a small number of exemptions for certain categories of traveller. You can find further information by visiting the Macao Government Tourism Board website.    Residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan or mainland China who have travelled overseas in the 21 days prior to their arrival will also be denied entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211006191551/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/macao/entry-requirements

so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Individuals may book an appointment at one of Macauâs approved COVID-19 testing locations. Macau Health App is used to enter a vast range of buildings and provide status on individuals    Public spaces and services  Macao has introduced a QR three-colour code system, which replaces the previous digital health declaration needed at border checkpoints and for entering public administration premises, casinos and other venues. The new code requires its users to confirm whether they have been in COVID-19 quarantine at home or in a government-run facility and consists of three colours: red, yellow, green. Visitors receiving red or yellow codes may be subject to testing, hospitalisation or restrictions on their movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211006190719/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/macao/coronavirus

The Ministry of Health and Sports is conducting disease surveillance and surveillance activities to identify those who have been in close contact with laboratory-confirmed patients for the prevention and control of COVID-19 disease. In doing so, we are identifying those who have been in close contact with the patient for 2 days before the onset of symptoms and within 14 days after the onset of symptoms, based on the recommendations of the World Health Organization (WHOID).    The laboratory-confirmed patients and their families and their places of residence; People who worked together Close contacts Strict home quarantine is being monitored for those who travel together during the trip. The participation of all members of the public, including family members, is especially needed in such monitoring.    Therefore, the Ministry of Health and Sports is announcing the visit to public places within 2 days before the onset of symptoms and 14 days after the onset of the symptoms of laboratory confirmation patients, and urges the public who have been in contact with these patients to contact the nearest administration and health department as soon as possible.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211011034039/https://mohs.gov.mm/page/8509

For those who passed through risky countries, 10 day quarantine is mandatory.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211129032819/https://mn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

It is compulsory to show a PCR test taken within 72 hours before boarding and on arrival with negative results.  Vaccinated travellers are not exempted from quarantine. Only travellers with health conditions with valid proof of documentation and approval from the Ministry of Health can be quarantined at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129144530/https://www.kln.gov.my/web/gbr_london/home/-/asset_publisher/pXgtFN47qQjc/blog/faqs-travelling-to-malaysia?inheritRedirect=false

PSU 4.0 will be implemented over four months from Aug 1, 2021. A total allocation of RM3.8 billion (896.6 million USD) would be channelled to qualified employers and limited to 500 workers for each company.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129230302/https://www.mof.gov.my/portal/en/news/press-citations/govt-allocates-rm3-8-bln-for-4-month-psu-4-0-from-aug-1-tengku-zafrul

Face coverings are required across Malaysia    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018163341/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malaysia/coronavirus

Auckland remains at Alert Level 3 Step 2.     The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2    Schools  Akonga (students) in Years 11, 12 and 13 in Alert Level 3 areas are able to return to school. Akonga who are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 should continue to learn from home, unless they are fully vaccinated.    Tamariki (children) and rangatahi (young people) in Years 1 to 10 should continue to learn from home â unless their parents or carers need to go to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/
No change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206171616/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news?start=30

Auckland remains at Alert Level 3 Step 2.   The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2    At Step 2, retail can open, with customers keeping 2 metres apart. Staff and customers are required to wear face coverings. Outdoor organised exercise classes, like yoga and bootcamps, can expand to 25 people (including instructors), with 2-metre physical distancing required.    At Step 2, customers cannot enter business premises to consume food, regardless of whether they are seated indoors or outdoors, or if they are bringing their own food.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122172733/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/alert-level-3-steps-1-to-3/
No change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206171616/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news?start=30

The Philippines Department of Education (DepEd) began implementation a pilot program for resuming face-to-face teaching in schools on November 16th 2021, with around 100 public schools taking part. Private schools are being treated as part of a separate program. The remainder of schools are still closed. Links below are for the DepEd official statement and a page from the Department of Health website with the list of schools in the program:    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203164436/https://www.deped.gov.ph/2021/11/16/on-the-start-of-pilot-implementation-of-limited-face-to-face-classes/   https://web.archive.org/web/20211203164955/https://doh.gov.ph/node/33781

"The Philippines will extend COVID-19 alert level measures to all other areas in phases from Nov. 12. Officials currently employ a multi-tier alert level system for applying COVID-19-related restrictions in selected areas, consisting of alert levels 1 through 5 in order of increasingly strict controls."    "Level 4: The locations include Aurora, Bacolod City, Negros Oriental, and Davao Occidental. Residents aged below 18 or above 65 years old, as well as pregnant and immunocompromised people, must remain at home in all areas. Nonessential tourist attractions and entertainment venues are closed. Meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE) are not allowed. Non-essential social gatherings are banned. Food establishments may offer indoor and outdoor dine-in services at varying capacity limits; only fully vaccinated individuals can dine in. Businesses with the Safety Seal certification are allowed to operate at an additional 10 percent capacity."    The alert level system (taken from the second link below) says the following: "Except those located in areas covered by granular lockdowns, all other establishments, or activities not prohibited under each Alert Level may be allowed to operate on-site provided they implement the minimum public health standards. However, they are encouraged to operate with a minimal on-site capacity, while applying work-from-home and other flexible work arrangements. For this purpose, the movement of workers of said establishments residing in areas not covered by granular lockdowns shall remain unrestricted."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211128065308/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/544361/philippines-authorities-to-extend-covid-19-alert-level-measures-to-all-other-areas-in-phases-from-nov-12-update-80    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122154037/https://mirror.pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/20211111-IATF-Guidelines.pdf    Offices are open subject to these guidelines: https://web.archive.org/web/20211203171102/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/economic/jobs

Changed to alert levels from November 12. Alert level 4 areas: "The locations include Aurora, Bacolod City, Negros Oriental, and Davao Occidental. Meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE), as well as dine-in services, social gatherings, tourist attractions, and selected entertainment venues, may take place for fully vaccinated individuals at 10 and 30-percent capacity at indoor and outdoor locations respectively. Businesses must have the Safety Seal certification."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203170113/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/544361/philippines-authorities-to-extend-covid-19-alert-level-measures-to-all-other-areas-in-phases-from-nov-12-update-80

Restrictions in gatherings are based on the capacity of indoor spaces but there is no mention of any clear cut-off point.  Changed to alert levels from November 12. Alert level 4 areas: "The locations include Aurora, Bacolod City, Negros Oriental, and Davao Occidental. Meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE), as well as dine-in services, social gatherings, tourist attractions, and selected entertainment venues, may take place for fully vaccinated individuals at 10 and 30-percent capacity at indoor and outdoor locations respectively. Businesses must have the Safety Seal certification."    Capacity of buildings allowed depend on the alert level of the area, but Targeted can't be put down here. So there are differing capacity limits in a targeted manner.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203170113/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/544361/philippines-authorities-to-extend-covid-19-alert-level-measures-to-all-other-areas-in-phases-from-nov-12-update-80

Intrazonal and interzonal travel shall be allowed subject to the reasonable regulations of the LGU of destination, except for those (i) below eighteen (18) years of age, and (ii) belonging to the vulnerable population, namely, those who are over sixty-five (65) years of age, those with immunodeficiencies, comorbidities, or other health risks, and pregnant women.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122154037/https://mirror.pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/20211111-IATF-Guidelines.pdf

Alert Level 4: "The locations include Aurora, Bacolod City, Negros Oriental, and Davao Occidental. Residents aged below 18 or above 65 years old, as well as pregnant and immunocompromised people, must remain at home in all areas, though some exemptions are in place."    "Intrazonal and interzonal travel shall be allowed subject to the reasonable regulations of the LGU of destination, except for those (i) below eighteen (18) years of age, and (ii) belonging to the vulnerable population, namely, those who are over sixty-five (65) years of age, those with immunodeficiencies, comorbidities, or other health risks, and pregnant women, provided that:     a. Those below eighteen (18) years of age, and those belonging to the vulnerable population, shall be allowed access to obtain essential goods and services, or for work in permitted industries and offices in accordance with existing labor laws, rules, and regulations.  b. Fully vaccinated individuals belonging to the vulnerable population and those below eighteen (18) years of age shall be allowed to participate in the following activities:      i. Specialized markets of the Department of Tourism such as Point-to-Point Travel subject to the reasonable regulations of the LGU of destination, and Staycations; and      ii. Individual outdoor exercises even beyond the general area of their respective residences. Provided that, the minimum public health standards and precautions such as the wearing of face masks and the maintenance of social distancing protocols are observed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203175048/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/544361/philippines-authorities-to-extend-covid-19-alert-level-measures-to-all-other-areas-in-phases-from-nov-12-update-80    https://web.archive.org/web/20211122154037/https://mirror.pcoo.gov.ph/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/20211111-IATF-Guidelines.pdf
